issues.text: Whether the legality of the demand notice dated December 2, 1949, can be challenged by the petitioner on the strength of the provisions of the Constitution, because the Constitution is prospective and not retrospective

anchor.surface_text: the principal point taken on their behalf is that the legality of the demand notice dated December 2, 1949, cannot be challenged by the petitioner on the strength of the provisions of the Constitution, because the Constitution is prospective and not retrospective secondly,

issues.text: Whether the subsequent proceedings taken in pursuance of the demand notice dated December 2, 1949 do in any way violate the right of equal protection of the laws guaranteed under Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: it is contended on behalf of the respondents that the subsequent proceedings taken in pursuance of the demand notice aforesaid do not in any way violate the right of equal protection of the laws guaranteed under Art. 14 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether on the construction of s. 8-A of the Act, after the order made by the Central Government under sub-s. (2) thereof, a fresh assessment was necessary and as no such assessment was made, all subsequent proceedings for recovery of the tax are illegal

anchor.surface_text: On the construction of s. 8-A of the Act it has been argued that after the order made by the Central Government under sub-s.  2  thereof, a fresh assessment was necessary and as no such assessment was made, all subsequent proceedings for recovery of the tax are illegal.

issues.text: Whether the petitioner received the demand notice dated December 2, 1949 before the coming into force of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: In his petition the petitioner has stated that he received the demand notice dated December 2, 1949 in or about April, 1950. In the counter-affidavit of the respondents it has been stated that the assessee was informed of the demand early in December, 1949.

issues.text: Whether the main contention that the proceedings taken against the petitioner in pursuance of the order under s. 8-A (2) are violative of the guarantee of equal protection of the laws under Art. 14 of the Constitution

arguments.court_reasoning: No discriminatory procedure post-Constitution; reasonable classification of tax evaders with uniform recovery

anchor.surface_text: It is convenient at this stage to refer to some of the earlier decisions of this Court on the question of constitutionality of some of the provisions of the Act. On May 28, 1954, this Court delivered judgment in Suraj Mall Mohta...

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished: those involved discriminatory procedure/investigation post-Constitution; here all pre-Constitution

arguments.claim: Constitution prospective not retrospective; pre-Constitution proceedings not challengeable under Art.14

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the statement as correct. On the materials in the record it is clear that the proceedings against the petitioner culminating in the service of the notice of demand against him were all completed before the coming into force of the Constitution and the petitioner cannot challenge those proceedings under Art. 14 of the Constitution for it is well settled that the Constitution is prospective and not retrospective.

arguments.claim: No fresh assessment required under s.8-A(2); direct recovery as arrears under ss.44,46 IT Act
Petitioner belongs to reasonable class of tax evaders/settlers; s.8-A(2) procedure non-discriminatory under Art.14
Prior decisions distinguished as they involved post-Constitution discriminatory procedures

holdings.text: The proceedings against the petitioner culminating in the service of the notice of demand against him were all completed before the coming into force of the Constitution and the petitioner cannot challenge those proceedings under Art. 14 of the Constitution for it is well settled that the Constitution is prospective and not retrospective.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows petitioner informed of demand in Dec 1949, made partial payments without objection; doctrine of prospectivity well-settled.

holdings.text: On the construction of s. 8-A of the Act, after the order made by the Central Government under sub-s. (2) thereof, no fresh assessment was necessary; ss. 44 and 46 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 apply directly to recovery of settlement sums as arrears.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.8-A(2) distinguishes from s.8; directs enforcement of settlement terms via IT Act recovery provisions without assessment.

holdings.text: The petitioner has not been subjected to a discriminatory procedure under Art.14; proceedings under s.8-A(2) including recovery via ss.44,46 do not violate equal protection.
holdings.reasoning_summary: All key steps including demand notice pre-Constitution; no post-Constitution discrimination.

holdings.text: The procedure under s.8-A(2) does not discriminate against petitioner vis-a-vis other debtors; petitioner belongs to reasonable class of tax evaders/settlers with uniform recovery having rational nexus to tax recovery object.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Art.14 reasonable classification test: class of tax evaders/settlers distinct from general contractual debtors; uniform procedure rationally related to recovery.

holdings.text: Subsequent proceedings in pursuance of the demand notice do not violate Art.14 equal protection.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No discriminatory procedure post-Constitution; reasonable classification upheld.

holdings.text: Prior decisions like Suraj Mall Mohta, Shree Meenakshi Mills, Muthiah, Basheshar Nath distinguished as they involved discriminatory procedures applied after Constitution came into force.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual distinction: all proceedings here pre-Constitution unlike prior cases.

precedents.cited_proposition: sub-section (4) of section 5 of the Taxation on Income (Investigation Commission) Act, 1947 was bad as it offended Article 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: In Shree Meenakshi Mills Ltd., Madurai V. V. Viswanatha Sastri and Another 2 , sub-s.  1  of s. 5 of the Act was held to be bad on that ground.

precedents.case_name: Shree Meenakshi Mills Ltd., Madurai v. V. Viswanatha Sastri and Another
precedents.cited_proposition: sub-section (1) of section 5 of the Act was bad because Income-tax Officer could pick some substantial tax evaders for reference under the Act while dealing with others under amended section 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act

precedents.citation: M. CT. Muthiah two Others v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras Another 3

anchor.surface_text: Finally, on December 20, 1955, came the decision of this Court in M. CT. Muthiah two Others v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras Another  3 .

precedents.case_name: M. CT. Muthiah and two Others v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras and Another
precedents.cited_proposition: cases concluded by reports and directions under section 8(2) before 26 January 1950 valid, but pending investigations or assessments hit by Article 14
precedents.cited_holding: The result, therefore, is that barring the cases of persons which were already concluded by reports made by the Commission and the directions given by the Central Government under section 8(2) of the Act XXX of 1947 culminating in the assessment or reassessment of the escaped income, those cases which were pending on the 26th January 1950 for investigation before the Commission as also the assessment or reassessment proceedings which were pending on the 26th January 1950 before the Income-tax Officers concerned in pursuance of the directions given by the Central Government under section 8(2) of the Act would be hit by Article 14 of the Constitution and would be invalidated.

precedents.citation: Basheshar Nath v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi Rajasthan and Another 1

precedents.case_name: Basheshar Nath v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi Rajasthan and Another
precedents.cited_proposition: settlement under s. 8-A after commencement of Constitution bad as result of discriminatory procedure continued after commencement

precedents.cited_proposition: settlement vitiated by discriminatory procedure adopted after commencement of Constitution
